column1: Write a JUnit test method for the Java method described below. The test method should have proper and relevant assert statements and avoid repetition of assert statements.

Write a JUnit test method for the Java method described below. The test method should have proper and relevant assert statements and avoid repetition of assert statements. @Test public void testName() { /*assertEquals(expectedResult, actualResult); assertTrue(someCondition); assertFalse(someCondition); */} Class: ChartEditorManager, Method: getChartEditorFactory Description: /** * Returns the current factory. * * @return The current factory (never null). */

Write a JUnit test method for the Java method described below. The test method should have proper and relevant assert statements and avoid repetition of assert statements. @Test public void testName() { /*assertEquals(expectedResult, actualResult); assertTrue(someCondition); assertFalse(someCondition); */} Class: ChartEditorManager, Method: setChartEditorFactory Description: /** * Sets the chart editor factory. * * @param f the new factory (null not permitted). */

Write a JUnit test method for the Java method described below. The test method should have proper and relevant assert statements and avoid repetition of assert statements.
@Test public void testName() { /*assertEquals(expectedResult, actualResult); assertTrue(someCondition); assertFalse(someCondition); */}
Class: ChartEditorManager, Method: getChartEditor
Description: /**
* Returns a component that can be used to edit the given chart.
*
* @param chart  the chart.
*
* @return The chart editor.
*/
